00017 =head1 NAME
00018 
00019 answerComposition.pl - An answer checker that determines if two functions
00020 compose to form a given function.
00021 
00022 =head1 DESCRIPTION
00023 
00024 answerComposition.pl provides an answer checker that determines if two functions
00025 compose to form a given function. This can be used in problems where you ask a
00026 student to break a given function into a composition of two simpler functions,
00027 neither of which is allowed to be the identity function.
00028 
00029 =cut
00030 
00031 sub _answerComposition_init {}; # don't reload this file
00032 
00033 =head1 MACROS
00034 
00035 =head2 COMPOSITION_ANS
00036 
00037     COMPOSITION_ANS($f, $g, %options)
00038 
00039 An answer checked to see if $f composed with $g matches a given function,where
00040 $f and $g are one possible decomposition of the target function, and options are
00041 any of the options allowed by composition_ans_list() below.
00042 
00043 $f and $g are used to display the "correct" answer, and the composition is
00044 computed from them.
00045 
00046 This function actually supplies TWO answer checkers, for the two previous answer
00047 blanks.  So be sure to call it immediately after the answer blanks have been
00048 supplied. (It may be best to use the NAMED_COMPOSITION_ANS checker below, which
00049 specifies the answer blanks explicitly.)
00050 
00051 Example:
00052 
00053     BEGIN_TEXT
00054     \(f\circ g = (1+x)^2\) when
00055     \(f(x)\) = \{ans_rule(20)\} and \(g(x)\) = \{ans_rule(20)\}
00056     END_TEXT
00057     COMPOSITION_ANS("x^2","1+x");
00058 
00059 =cut
00060 
00061 sub COMPOSITION_ANS {
00062   my $f = shift; my $g = shift;
00063   my $num_of_answers = main::ans_rule_count();
00064   my $fID = ANS_NUM_TO_NAME($num_of_answers-1);
00065   my $gID = ANS_NUM_TO_NAME($num_of_answers);
00066   my %ans = composition_ans_list($fID=>$f,$gID=>$g,@_);
00067   ANS($ans{$fID},$ans{$gID});
00068 }
00069 
00070 =head2 NAMED_COMPOSITION_ANS
00071 
00072  NAMED_COMPOSITION_ANS($fID=>$f, $gID=>$g, %options)
00073 
00074 An answer checked to see if $f composed with $g matches a given function, where
00075 $fID and $gID are the names of the answer rules for the functions $f and $g, and
00076 $f and $g are the answers for the functions. %options are any of the options
00077 allowed by composition_ans_list() below.
00078 
00079 This routine allows you to put the answer blanks for $f and $g at any location
00080 in the problem, and in any order.
00081 
00082 Example:
00083 
00084  BEGIN_TEXT
00085  \(g\circ f = (1+x)^2\) when
00086  \(f(x)\) = \{NAMED_ANS('f',20)\} and \(g(x)\) = \{NAMED_ANS('g',20)\}
00087  END_TEXT
00088  NAMED_COMPOSITION_ANS(f => "x^2", g => "1+x");
00089 
00090 =cut
00091 
00092 sub NAMED_COMPOSITION_ANS {NAMED_ANS(composition_ans_list(@_))}
00093 
00094 =head2 composition_ans_list
00095 
00096  composition_ans_list($fID=>$f, $gID=>$g, %options)
00097 
00098 This is an internal routine that returns the named answer checkers
00099 used by COMPOSITION_ANS and NAMED_COMPOSITION_ANS above.
00100 
00101 $fID and $gID are the names of the answer rules for the functions and $f and $g
00102 are the answers for these functions. %options are from among:
00103 
00104 =over
00105 
00106 =item S<C<< var => 'x' >>>
00107 
00108 the name of the variable to use when
00109 both functions use the same one
00110 
00111 =item S<C<< vars => ['x','t'] >>>
00112 
00113 the names of the variables for $f and $g
00114 
00115 =item S<C<< showVariableHints => 1 or 0 >>>
00116 
00117 do/don't show errors when the variable
00118 used by the student is incorrect
00119 
00120 =back
00121 
00122 =cut
00123 
00124 sub composition_ans_list {
00125   my ($fID,$f,$gID,$g,%params) = @_; my @IDs = ($fID,$gID);
00126   #
00127   #  Get options
00128   #
00129   $params{vars} = [$params{var},$params{var}] if $params{var} && !$params{vars};
00130   $params{showVariableHints} = 1 unless defined($params{showVariableHints});
00131   my $isPreview = $main::inputs_ref->{previewAnswers};
00132   my $vars = $params{vars} || [];
00133   my @options = (ignoreInfinity=>0,ignoreStrings=>0);
00134   my ($i,$error);
00135 
00136   #
00137   #  Get correct answer data and determine which variables to use
00138   #
00139   $f = Value->Package("Formula")->new($f); $g = Value->Package("Formula")->new($g);
00140   my %correct = ($fID => $f, $gID => $g);
00141   my %x = ($fID => $vars->[0], $gID => $vars->[1]);
00142   foreach $i (@IDs) {
00143     unless ($x{$i}) {
00144       die "Can't tell which variable to use for $correct{$i}: ".
00145              "use var=>'x' or vars=>['x','y'] to specify it"
00146     if scalar(keys %{$correct{$i}->{variables}}) > 1;
00147       $x{$i} = (keys %{$correct{$i}->{variables}})[0];
00148     }
00149     die "$correct{$i} is not a function of $x{$i}"
00150       unless defined($correct{$i}->{variables}{$x{$i}});
00151   }
00152   my %y = ($fID => $x{$gID}, $gID => $x{$fID});
00153   my %ans = ($fID => message_cmp($f), $gID => message_cmp($g));
00154   my $fog = $f->substitute($x{$fID}=>$g);  #  the composition
00155 
00156   #
00157   #  Check that the student formulas parse OK,
00158   #  produce a number, contain the correct variable,
00159   #  don't contain the composition itself in a simple way,
00160   #  and aren't the identity.
00161   #
00162   my %student = ($fID => $main::inputs_ref->{$fID},
00163          $gID => $main::inputs_ref->{$gID});
00164   foreach $i (@IDs) {
00165     next unless defined($student{$i});
00166     $student{$i} = Parser::Formula($student{$i});
00167     if (!defined($student{$i})) {$error = 1; next}
00168     $ans{$i}->{rh_ans}{preview_latex_string} = $student{$i}->TeX;
00169     if ($student{$i}->type ne 'Number') {
00170       $ans{$i} = $correct{$i}->cmp(@options);
00171       $error = 1; next;
00172     }
00173     if ($x{$fID} ne $x{$gID} && defined($student{$i}->{variables}{$y{$i}})) {
00174       $ans{$i}->{rh_ans}{ans_message} = "Your formula may not contain $y{$i}"
00175     unless $isPreview || !$params{showVariableHints};
00176       $error = 1; next;
00177     }
00178     if (!defined($student{$i}->{variables}{$x{$i}})) {
00179       $ans{$i}->{rh_ans}{ans_message} = "Your formula is not a function of $x{$i}"
00180     unless $isPreview || !$params{showVariableHints};
00181       $error = 1; next;
00182     }
00183     if (($student{$i}->{tree}->class eq 'BOP' &&
00184      ($fog == $student{$i}->{tree}{lop} || $fog == $student{$i}->{tree}{rop})) ||
00185     ($student{$i}->{tree}->class eq 'UOP' && $fog == $student{$i}->{tree}{op})) {
00186       $ans{$i}->{rh_ans}{ans_message} =
00187         "Your formula may not have the composition as one of its terms";
00188       $error = 1; next;
00189     }
00190     if ($fog == $student{$i}) {
00191       $ans{$i}->{rh_ans}{ans_message} =
00192     "Your formula my not be the composition itself";
00193       $error = 1; next;
00194     }
00195     if (Parser::Formula($x{$i}) == $student{$i}) {
00196       $ans{$i}->{rh_ans}{ans_message} = "The identity function is not allowed"
00197     unless $isPreview;
00198       $error = 1; next;
00199     }
00200 
00201   }
00202 
00203   #
00204   #  If no error, and both answers are given, check if compositions are equal
00205   #
00206   if (!$error && defined($student{$fID}) && defined($student{$gID})) {
00207     if ($fog == $student{$fID}->substitute($x{$fID}=>$student{$gID})) {
00208       $ans{$fID}->{rh_ans}{score} = $ans{$gID}->{rh_ans}{score} = 1;
00209     }
00210   }
00211 
00212   return (%ans);
00213 }
00214 
00215 =head2 message_cmp
00216 
00217  message_cmp($correct)
00218 
00219 Returns an answer evaluator that always returns incorrect, with a given error
00220 message. Used by COMPOSITION_ANS to produce "dummy" answer checkers for the two
00221 parts of the composition.
00222 
00223 =cut
00224 
00225 sub message_cmp {
00226   my $correct = shift;
00227   my $answerEvaluator = new AnswerEvaluator;
00228   $answerEvaluator->ans_hash(
00229      type => "message",
00230      correct_ans => $correct->string,
00231      ans_message => $message,
00232   );
00233   $answerEvaluator->install_evaluator(sub {shift});
00234   return $answerEvaluator;
00235 }
00236 
00237 1;
